description: Borrowed from French apologue, from Latin apologus from Ancient Greek ἀπόλογος (apólogos, “story, tale, fable”) from ἀπό- (apó-, “off, away from”) + λόγος (lógos, “speech”).

entries.meaning: A short story with a moral, often involving talking animals or objects; a fable.
examples: […]  but though the mythic hero may thus be made to figure in a moral apologue, an imagination so little in keeping with his unethic nature jars upon the reader's mind.

entries.meaning: (rhetoric) The use of fable to persuade the audience.
